topic_metadata.title: Why can I not edit a map value assigned to another variable?

posts.name: Climate Defiance
posts.cooked:
The following code modifies the array in a.

      let a = ("fda": (1,2,3))
      a.at("fda").push(4)

The following code does not, why?

      let a = ("fda": (1,2,3))
      let b = a.at("fda")
      b.push(4)

V 0.13.0
posts.raw:
The following code modifies the array in a.
```
      let a = ("fda": (1,2,3))
      a.at("fda").push(4)
```

The following code does not, why?
```
      let a = ("fda": (1,2,3))
      let b = a.at("fda")
      b.push(4)
```

V 0.13.0

posts.name: Baryhobal
posts.cooked:
When assigning to a variable, you will actually get a copy of the array (in reality, it’s a bit more complicated iirc but it doesn’t matter in practice)
In the first case however, you directly access the value in the dictionary, thus modifying it
posts.raw:
When assigning to a variable, you will actually get a copy of the array (in reality, it's a bit more complicated iirc but it doesn't matter in practice)
In the first case however, you directly access the value in the dictionary, thus modifying it

posts.name: Climate Defiance
posts.cooked: can I avoid creating a copy when assigning to a variable?
posts.raw: can I avoid creating a copy when assigning to a variable?

posts.name: Baryhobal
posts.cooked: No you cannot (afaik), as that would probably break function purity, although I’m not sure that is the reason for this design choice
posts.raw: No you cannot (afaik), as that would probably break function purity, although I'm not sure that is the reason for this design choice
